definition: A molecule that carries the genetic instructions used in growth and development and reproduction.
A segment of DNA that determines a specific trait or function.
A structure made of DNA and protein that contains many genes.
The process of changing the DNA of an organism.
Creating an exact copy of an organism or cell.
A change in the DNA sequence of a gene.
Microscopic organisms often used in biotechnology to produce medicines like insulin.
A hormone that helps control blood sugar often made using genetically engineered bacteria.
Using living organisms or systems to develop useful products.
All the genetic material in an organism.
A technique used to make many copies of a DNA segment.
A molecule made by cells that performs many functions in the body.
A type of protein that speeds up chemical reactions in cells.
A small circular piece of DNA found in bacteria often used in genetic engineering.
DNA that is formed by combining DNA from two different sources.
An organism that contains genes from a different species.
A cell that can develop into many different types of cells.
A container used to grow organisms for use in industrial biotechnology.
A modern gene-editing tool that can precisely change DNA.
A substance that helps the body develop protection against disease.
A protein produced by the immune system that recognizes and binds to foreign substances.
A vehicle (often a virus or plasmid) used to deliver genetic material into a cell.
A technique that treats disease by inserting or altering or removing genes within an individual's cells.
A lab technique used to separate DNA or RNA or proteins based on size and charge.
The process of determining the order of nucleotides in a DNA molecule.
The process of determining the location of genes on a chromosome.
The process of determining the exact order of nucleotides in a DNA molecule.
A laboratory tool used to measure and transfer very small volumes of liquid.
The genetic makeup of an organism.
The observable traits or characteristics of an organism resulting from its genotype.
A jelly-like substance used in electrophoresis to separate DNA fragments.
A cell into which foreign DNA is introduced during genetic engineering.
A gene or DNA sequence used to identify a particular sequence or trait.
A process of combining two different genetic sequences to form a hybrid.
A gene that has been deliberately inactivated in a living organism.
A tool used to detect the expression of thousands of genes at once.
An enzyme that joins DNA fragments together.
An enzyme that cuts DNA at specific sequences.
A non-human species used in research to understand biological processes.
Medicines produced using biotechnology often involving proteins or nucleic acids.
The process of making multiple copies of a specific gene.
The total genetic diversity found within a population or species.
The process of copying a segment of DNA into RNA.
The process of converting mRNA into a protein.
The large-scale study of proteins particularly their functions and structures.
A substance formed during metabolism (often measured in biotechnology studies).
The use of computer technology to manage and analyze biological data.
The study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs.
An interdisciplinary field that involves designing and constructing new biological parts and devices and systems.
The process by which information from a gene is used to synthesize a functional gene product (usually protein).
A technique used to reduce or eliminate the expression of a specific gene.
The process of making precise changes to the DNA of an organism.
